title: Template for Deploying to AWS EC2
description:
### Problem to solve

<!-- What problem do we solve? -->

We want to help our users deploy easily to AWS

### Intended users

* [Dana (Data Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#dana-data-analyst)

Personas are described at https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/ -->

* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)

### Further details

<!-- Include use cases, benefits, and/or goals (contributes to our vision?) -->

Following comment https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/2351#note_263237910

I think just having gitlab-ci.yml template added for AWS (deploy to EC2, ECS, Fargate) would suffice in the short term. We can even use the tool we suggest in our [documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/examples/deployment/).

I feel that most customers would like to understand our best practices and documentation around how to best deploy using our product and what's needed to be successful. Adding into AutoDevops functionality would be most awesome, but that may be a different issue.

### Proposal

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->

Create a `gitlab-ci.yml` template for deploying to AWS EC2 using [Using Dpl as deployment tool](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/examples/deployment/)

Actions needed to be done

* [ ] Create `gitlab-ci.yml` template
* [ ] Create documentation on how to use the template 

We can later expand on this and add deploying to  ECS, Fargate.

title: Refactor package details frontend in preparation for upcoming improvements
description:
## Summary

Refactor some of the package ~frontend code in anticipation of more package registries and changing the ~UX to match the new container registry. 

## Improvements

There are two main areas which we can improve:

* Package details `installation` instruction components
* Preparing for the merge of the list and details views into an SPA structure

My proposal would be to:

1. Convert how the existing package installation instructions are generated from computed props in single components to using `getters` from the Vuex store.
	* This could be a single MR where we move the logic from the computed props to the `getters`, then update the existing components to use these getters (with new tests).
2. Change the implementation of specific installation components for each package type to a generic one that uses the store.
	* This will also be a single MR to remove the existing `installation` components and convert to a single component.
3. Do the same for the `information` component and generate the package info from the store.
	* This is a single MR too as it's unrelated to the other two, it could be deferred or worked on later (there are some outstanding questions around certain package types metadata).

The goal of this is to move most of the installation and information logic into the store where it can be shared across different views.

The next step would be to change the package ~frontend to work like the new container registry using the Vue Router. This means we'll be using one store for both the list and detail views, giving us extra options like showing installation instructions directly on the list page, etc. This work will be a separate issue spread across a number of MR's and any ~UX enhancements will also follow as new issues.

## Risks

* Package installation features may be effected but the risk is very low.

## Involved components

* `ee/app/assets/javascripts/packages/details/components/*.vue`
* `ee/app/assets/javascripts/packages/details/store/*.js`

## Optional: Intended side effects

* Will reduce the amount of code the ~frontend needs

## Optional: Missing test coverage

* Should reduce the amount of repeated / similar tests for the `installation` components

title: Implement pipelines for merged results in `gitlab-org/gitlab` pipeline
description:
## Objective

Reduce the number of broken masters due to branches which were behind master and have a successful MR pipeline but fail in master.

## Proposal 

Steps taken from https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/quality/team-tasks/issues/195#note_279239095

- [x] Enable `disable_merge_trains` feature flag. e.g. `/chatops run feature set disable_merge_trains --project=gitlab-org/gitlab true` => Done on 2020-02-17.
- [x] Add documentation guidance for steps Maintainers will need to do (tentative date: 2020-02-18):
  - Maintainer runs an extra pipeline via "Merge Request tab > Run Pipeline button" and set MWPS. This means the pipeline result is based on the latest `master` even though the feature branch is behind some commits.
  - Forked pipeline workflow can follow the current workflow of merging.
  - [x] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/25449 and https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/-/merge_requests/41397
- [x] Ask current maintainers for feedback (tentative date: 2020-02-24) 
- [x] Communicate broadly (tentative date: 2020-02-26):
  - [x] Company call
  - [x] Eng. week-in-review
  - [x] Slack: `#development`, `#backend`, `#frontend`, `#quality`, `#backend_maintainers`, `#frontend_maintainers`, `#ux_maintainers`
- [x] Enable "Merge pipelines will try to validate the post-merge result prior to merging" (Settings > General > Merge Request) (tentative date: 2020-02-27)

**Advantages:**

- Authors won't have to rebase their branch as frequently anymore (basically, only when there are conflicts) since the Merge Results pipeline will already incorporate the latest changes from `master`. This should result in faster review/merge cycles since maintainers won't have to ask for a final rebase: instead, they'll only have to start a MR pipeline and set MWPS.
- This step should bring us very close to the actual Merge Trains feature by testing the Merge Results against the latest `master` at the time of the pipeline creation.

**Disadvantages:**

- Starting a MR pipeline before merging will increase the review/merge cycle time by a pipeline's duration.
- This will result in more Git refs (the merge refs) and more pipelines.

## Considerations

- Will this prevent merging if `master` is currently broken?
  - If maintainers start a MR pipeline + MWPS, yes it should prevent any merges into `master` until `master` is fixed (although, we don't enforce green pipelines as a condition to be able to merge (this is tracked at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/quality/team-tasks/issues/326).
- Will this feature prevent a merge if the pipeline is has a transient/flaky failure?
  - Yes, but the problem can already occurs currently, and retrying the failing job usually solves it.

title: Display downstream pipeline errors in upstream pipelines (UX improvement)
description:
### Summary

When triggering downstream pipelines they can error out. We should be able to display these errors in the upstream bridge job.

![Screen_Shot_2020-04-07_at_15.07.38](/uploads/ae6f82782d8284b948c96f473cc4daa3/Screen_Shot_2020-04-07_at_15.07.38.png)

### Proposal

We can reach failure reasons of downstream pipelines via `Ci::Bridge#sourced_pipelines`.

However, we don't always create downstream pipelines. Examples:
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/12-9-stable-ee/app/services/ci/create_cross_project_pipeline_service.rb#L52

After implementing #213666, in this issue, we need store failure reason information of downstream pipelines in bridges. (More discussions about it: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/28120#note_312091893)

Then we can have this behavior:

![Screen_Shot_2020-03-26_at_17.49.17](/uploads/61a993c569ffe152bda5dd15c5393764/Screen_Shot_2020-03-26_at_17.49.17.png)

---

We also need to add failure reason for strategy:depend situations. We may do this in another issue/MR.

Discussion: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/28120#note_318999395

> I would also consider adding `downstream_pipeline_failed` failure reason to a the list of failure reasons supported by `Ci::Bridge`. It seems like a small effort, and might improve the situation here significantly. We probably would need to add this to `self.drop!(...)` in `Ci::Bridge#inherit_status_from_downstream`

---

<details>
<summary>Old Proposal</summary>

1. Persist all pipeline creation errors in `Ci::Pipeline` model. Maybe we can reuse `Ci::Pipeline#yaml_errors` and rename it to `Ci::Pipeline#creation_errors`?
1. When creating a downstream pipeline we now persist always the association between bridge job and downstream pipeline, so we can always reference the downstream pipeline from the bridge job.
1. Change `Gitlab::Ci::Status::Build::Failed#failure_reason_message` to append related downstream pipeline errors if `failure_reason_message` is called to display bridge job errors.

We could look into changing the `failure_reason_message` to append any additional errors from the downstream pipeline.

```ruby
class Ci::Status::Build::Failed
  def failure_reason_message
    messages = []
    messages << self.class.reasons.fetch(subject.failure_reason.to_sym)
    messages += subject.additional_errors
    messages.join(', ')
  end
end

class Ci::Bridge
  def additional_errors
    return [] unless failure_reason == 'downstream_bridge_pipeline_creation_failed'
    
    # this is not performant and queries need to be optimized
    sourced_pipelines.map do |source_pipeline|
      source_pipeline.pipeline.yaml_errors
    end
  end
end

class Ci::Build
  def additional_errors
    []
  end
end
```

</details>

<details>
<summary>Technical Background</summary>

```
When triggering a downstream pipeline with a bridge job - if the downstream pipeline creation errors out (e.g. an invalid YAML config), the relationship between the bridge job and the downstream pipeline is not saved.

This is because the relation is being added in the `Seed` pipeline chain step and the chain is broken in `Confing::Content` or `Config::Process` which comes before `Seed`.

This is required for displaying the downstream creation errors in upstream bridges.
```

This was resolved with https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/207234
</details>


### Use cases to solve

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/204378
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/198354

title: Container expiration policy settings, hide form on API error
description:
Currently, the Docker container expiration policy settings form has one edge case where if the API fails the form is displayed regardless ( an appropriate error message is raised )

The issue is that the API call is also used to check if the Settings is available for the project ( only project created after 12.8 are eligible for this ) and so if the API fails the form is presented to the user and this may mislead them thinking that they can actually use the expiration policy on such project.

title: Changes will be lost if multiple people edit a wiki page
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

If several people edit a text in the wiki, the changes of those who did not press the "Save changes" button first will be lost.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Person A starts editing a wiki page
2. Person B starts editing the same wiki page like Person A
3. Person B saves his edit first
4. Person A saves his edit after Person B
5. Person A receives the message "Someone edited the page at the same time you did. Please check out the page and make sure your changes will not unintentionally remove theirs."
6. The changes of Person A in the editor are gone

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

The changes of Person A are gone after pressing the "Save changes" button

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Proposal 1: The changes of Person A are still available in the editor after pressing the "Save changes" button

Proposal 2: Person A is given the opportunity to merge his changes with the version Person B changed

title: Missing label titles for customizable cycle analytics form
description:
### Summary

* Label titles are not appearing in the label selector for customizable cycle analytics.
* Selecting a label does not correctly update the form data object

### Steps to reproduce

1. Navigate to `/-/analytics/cycle_analytics`
1. Select a group
1. Click `Add a stage`
1. Select a label based stage, ie `Issue label was added`
1. Try and select a label :scream:

Label colours render, but the title does not

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The titles should render

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

![Screen_Shot_2020-01-31_at_9.00.59_pm](/uploads/6b005d1c4084428c3abae84d4ae7daf0/Screen_Shot_2020-01-31_at_9.00.59_pm.png)

### Output of checks

Happening on staging

### Possible fixes

`ee/app/assets/javascripts/analytics/cycle_analytics/components/labels_selector.vue` - Line 44 and 59

title: Add section to GraphQL developer docs about how to deprecate
description:
We should add a section to the GraphQL developer docs to guide developers on deprecation best practices for the GraphQL schema.

#### Sections

Some ideas:

- What deprecating is
- How to deprecate (see **Standards**)
  - Example code
- How to avoid deprecation
- Mention about our upcoming plans to remove deprecated fields https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/Product/issues/507

#### Standards

##### `deprecation_reason`

```ruby
deprecation_reason: '<reason-for-deprecation>. Deprecated in <GitLab version>'
# e.g.:
deprecation_reason: 'Plain text token has been masked for security reasons. Deprecated in 12.8'

```

Where the field is being replaced with another one, `<reason-for-deprecation>` should specifically be:

```
Use `<other-field-name>`
```
```ruby
# e.g.:
deprecation_reason: 'Use `pipelines`. Deprecated in 12.8'
```

##### `description`

```ruby
description: '<existing description>. Deprecated in <GitLab version>: <reason-for-deprecation>'
# e.g.:
description: 'API token for the Grafana integration. Deprecated in 12.8: Plain text token has been masked for security reasons'
description: 'Latest pipeline of the commit. Deprecated in 12.8: Use `pipelines`'
```

title: [async_merge_request_check_mergeability] Enable asynchronous merge request mergeability check
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

## What

Remove the `async_merge_request_check_mergeability` feature flag when we see no negative effects on performance and worker is stable. The feature flag is introduced in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/merge_requests/21026.

## Owners

- Team: Create::Source Code
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_create_source_code`
- Best individual to reach out to: @patrickbajao 

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

Merge requests will still be marked as mergeable if there are no conflicts and no pending approval.

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

Merge requests don't get marked as mergeable even if there are no conflicts and no pending approval.

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

- https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/sidekiq-queue-detail/sidekiq-queue-detail?orgId=1&var-PROMETHEUS_DS=Global&var-environment=gprd&var-stage=main&var-queue=merge_request_mergeability_check
- https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/rPsQXrImk/rails-controller?orgId=1&refresh=1m&var-env=gprd&var-type=web&var-stage=main&var-controller=Projects::MergeRequestsController&var-action=show&var-action=show.json

## Beta groups/projects

If applicable, any groups/projects that are happy to have this feature turned on early. Some organizations may wish to test big changes they are interested in with a small subset of users ahead of time for example.

- `gitlab-org/gitlab` project

## Roll Out Steps

- [x] Enable on staging
- [x] Test on staging
- [x] Enable on dev.gitlab.org
- [x] Enable on GitLab.com for individual groups/projects listed above and verify behaviour
- [x] Coordinate a time to enable the flag with `#production` and `#g_delivery` on slack.
- [x] Announce on the issue an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com
- [x] Enable on GitLab.com by running chatops command in `#production`
- [x] Cross post chatops slack command to `#support_gitlab-com` and in your team channel
- [x] Announce on the issue that the flag has been enabled
- [x] Enable feature flag by default and add changelog entry

title: Use only the first line of the commit message on chat service notification
description:
From https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/23385#note_279834501

### Summary

Push commit notification to chat services (Discord, HangoutsChat, Mattermost, MicrosoftTeams, Slack, and UnifyCircuit (as of 12.7)) can be too long when one or more commit message(s) have multiple line in the new commits.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Whole commit messages are shown in chat notifications.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Only the first lines of commit message (almost same as commit message title) are shown in chat notifications.

### Problems

Due to this problem, we had to have workaround fix on gitlab-org/gitlab-foss!32180 (gitlab-org/gitlab-foss#65389)

title: Trigger the "Add additional seats" modal when groups are invited
description:
This issue is an improvement to [MVC: Show transparent warnings when adding a user to a group will incur a charge](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/35683).

### Problem

The Members page now allows the customer to add groups as well as individuals to their paid group. This was not accounted for in the original issue as the ability to add groups is new functionality. 

### Proposal

When a group is invited to a paid group via the Members page, the add seats modal should trigger if the `Max seats`/`Seats owed` number is going to be increased by the addition of the user/users that are being added to the group. 

cc @mkarampalas @amandarueda

epic.title: Charge customers properly when they add new users to a group on GitLab.com

title: Increment the "Max seats" and "Seats owed" values in real time as users are added
description:
This issue is an improvement to [MVC: Show transparent warnings when adding a user to a group will incur a charge](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/35683).

### Problem

When a user is added to a paid group and that additional user would increase the `Max seats` and `Seats owed` numbers in the UI, the values currently don't update instantly (they update once a day). It's a strange experience for the user to see the `Seats currently in use` number increment but not the other two.

### Proposal

After a user is added that would increase the `Max seats` and `Seats owed` values in the UI, the numbers should immediately update.

![SaaS___Group_members_page__above_seat_count](/uploads/ffafb7e44b235f2d4d8b86f75cc14453/SaaS___Group_members_page__above_seat_count.png)

cc @mkarampalas @amandarueda

epic.title: Charge customers properly when they add new users to a group on GitLab.com

title: Allow ingress managed app to be upgraded
description:
### Problem to solve

It is not currently possible to update the ingress managed app. Ingress is a fairly stable chart and the mechanism is already established. I believe this will simply need a couple lines of ~frontend to change (and verify behavior)

### Intended users

* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)

### Further details

### Proposal

To enable we need to add the `update-available` property to the UI. This should be auto-populated by any discrepancy in the rails model and serializer and so a pure frontend change should enable this feature.

Relevant code:
 - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/12-7-stable-ee/app/serializers/cluster_application_entity.rb#L14
 - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/12-7-stable-ee/app/assets/javascripts/clusters/components/applications.vue#L498
 - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/12-7-stable-ee/app/assets/javascripts/clusters/stores/clusters_store.js#L73

### Permissions and Security

No change to permissions

### Documentation

Update list of upgradeable applications: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/clusters/applications.html#upgrading-applications

### Availability & Testing

 * Upgrade from previous ingress to see if upgrade works as expected
   * Ensure traffic routes as expected
   * Prometheus stats are correctly exported
   * Certs are propagated by cert-manager

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

Customers can upgrade ingress without uninstalling and reinstalling it

### What is the type of buyer? 

~"GitLab Core" 

### Limitations

Due to limitations on [helm2/nginx chart](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/211758#note_308178842), updating/reinstalling nginx-ingress will be not be supported for different versions after this [change](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/27845) gets merged.

We have added a section under WAF documentation explaining what to expect from the UI and how to proceed with the most recent version: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/clusters/applications.html#waf-version-updates 

### Links / references

epic.title: Web Application Firewall - Minimal to Viable

title: Separate Redis instance/cluster for Elasticsearch indexing
description:
Since we want to mitigate risks during our large scale rollout of Advanced global search on Elasticsearch on GitLab.com we should have a separate Redis instance. This would allow us to be less risk averse when making changes because at the moment the most scary thing would be overloading Redis and breaking features outside of advanced search.

As we roll out Elasticsearch for all paid customers on GitLab.com we're also likely to expect massive increases in load on Redis so separating the instance would probably be something we eventually wanted to do anyway.

This would at least involve support from infra to get a separate Redis instance up and running. And then since we share the same Redis client for all sidekiq work we will likely need to build some middleware in there to isolate our workloads. Which has been discussed previously in https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/2391 and https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/118820 . We will want to kick start this and it may be possible for us to just start by namespacing our redis keys with some prefix.

It will also be important to have separate clear monitoring for this Redis instance so we can easily determine when we're nearing capacity.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Issues that we want to do but are not planned right now. Open for contribution from the community.

epic.title: Increase the stability of Advanced Search pipeline

title: Figure out why Elasticsearch was OOM
description:
From https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/production/issues/1591#note_277584126 and https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/search-team/team-tasks/issues/8#note_277880394 we believe that an Elasticsearch instance crashed due to out of memory.

This seemed to not resolve itself and cascaded a way that made the whole cluster stable.

So we want to understand:

1. [x] What caused the initial failure? Were we sending payloads that are too large? Were we sending too many requests? Something else?
1. [x] Why couldn't the system failover and recover since the cluster has redundancy?
1. [x] Do we need to resize the nodes and if so what is the appropriate size?

It's expected we may wish to involve Elastic support in order to help figure this out.

We may want to do another live experiment if we don't have enough logs to answer some of the above questions. We could  try enabling indexing without enabling searching then try to re-enable again for the big customer to simulate the same load. In order to do this we need to have a good handle on what safe levels are for sidekiq queues to know that we won't OOM Redis. We can also disable indexing as soon as the cluster becomes unstable which seemed quite quick last time and should still give us an opportunity to see what's happening.

It would also be great to try and simulate this on staging but the problem is that without real usage we may never be able to replicate what actually happened.

## Elastic Case

https://support.elastic.co/customers/s/case/5004M00000Yog8qQAB

epic.title: Increase the stability of Advanced Search pipeline

title: Monokai syntax highlighting theme for Web IDE
description:
### Problem to solve

<!-- What problem do we solve? -->

GitLab currently supports a `Monokai` syntax highlighting preference for viewing blobs in the repository. However, this is not supported when editing code inside of the Web IDE.

### Proposal

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->

Inside of the Web IDE we should support `Monokai` syntax preference based on [monokai.css](https://github.com/richleland/pygments-css/blob/master/monokai.css) which [GitLab uses](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/c10e3d611611982f78137337a94793a982cae03b/app/assets/stylesheets/highlight/themes/monokai.scss) in the blob viewer.

![webide-monokai-theme](/uploads/20b5f210fe830a97dd7847ed4b588d0a/webide-monokai-theme.png)

**Important Note:** In scope for this is only the code editing area. In a future iteration we'll work to expand themes to more of the viewable area in the Web IDE.

### Further details

<!-- Include use cases, benefits, and/or goals (contributes to our vision?) -->

Only the code editing pane will be in scope for this change, all sidebars will be out of scope for the initial implementation so that we can continue to evaluate the change across the application.

### Documentation

<!-- See the Feature Change Documentation Workflow https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature-change-workflow.html
Add all known Documentation Requirements here, per https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature-change-workflow.html#documentation-requirements
If this feature requires changing permissions, this document https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/permissions.html must be updated accordingly. -->

Documentation should be updated for the [Syntax highlighting theme](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/profile/preferences.html#syntax-highlighting-theme) to indicate which Themes are also supported in the Web IDE and that it also applies to the Web IDE.

epic.title: Use GitLab Syntax Highlighting Preference for Web IDE

title: Merge request diffs return 500 Internal Server Error "TypeError (no implicit conversion of nil into String)"
description:

For one of our projects, on certain merge requests, the merge request diff is returning 500 Internal Server Error. ### Steps to reproduce * Modify large files, in our case `.properties` files with `~9000 lines` encoded using `ISO-8859-1` or `UTF-8`. * Create merge request involving those files with several other files. * Consult the merge request and try to access the changes view of the MR. ### Example Project * We don't have an example project. * We cannot expose our internal project since it's a company proprietary code. ### What is the current *bug* behavior? As shown in the screenshots the merge request diffs does not show, so we cannot review the code. ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? title: Refresh_foreign_tables rake task was required during 12.4.x to 12.5.x Geo HA upgrade
description:
During the 12.4.x to 12.5.x Geo HA upgrade, after running post-deployment db migrations on secondary deploy node and then running `gitlab-ctl reconfigure`, we still needed to run gitlab-rake geo:db:refresh_foreign_tables (as recommended by the output of `gitlab-rake gitlab:geo:check`).  This step used to be in the instructions but was replaced by (1) waiting for primary migrations to finish/replicate, then (2) running `gitlab-ctl reconfigure`.

Let's investigate if this was user error and/or if the instructions should be modified.

cc @vsizov

title: CI Artifact upload 500 error
description:
Customer https://gitlab.my.salesforce.com/00161000004zoBW reported 500 errors on uploading CI artifacts to GitLab.com. 

Upon further investigation found the 500 errors:

Correlation search (returns 3 x 500 errors: https://log.gitlab.net/goto/6e2d38cf40c1ee03ba1d55c7620bc60c)

Useragent: `gitlab-runner 12.7.1 (12-7-stable; go1.13.5; linux/amd64)`

The error was not posted to Sentry, but I found the following stack traces in the logs:

```
lib/gitlab/git/wraps_gitaly_errors.rb:13:

in `block in cache_method_as_redis_set', app/models/repository.rb:259:
in `tag_exists?', app/models/repository.rb:201:
in `ambiguous_ref?', app/models/project.rb:2002:
in `protected_for?', app/models/ci/pipeline.rb:621:
in `block in protected_ref?', lib/gitlab/utils/strong_memoize.rb:30:
in `strong_memoize', app/models/ci/pipeline.rb:621:

in `block in predefined_commit_variables', app/models/ci/pipeline.rb:660:

in `predefined_commit_variables', app/models/ci/pipeline.rb:644:

in `predefined_variables', app/models/concerns/ci/contextable.rb:16:
in `block in scoped_variables', app/models/concerns/ci/contextable.rb:13:
in `tap', app/models/concerns/ci/contextable.rb:13:
in `scoped_variables', app/models/ci/build.rb:529:
in `block in variables', lib/gitlab/utils/strong_memoize.rb:30:

in `refspecs', ee/lib/gitlab/ip_address_state.rb:10:
```

Note that this is in the same piece of code block that we've been seeing problems: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/scalability/issues/124, however this repository only has a small number of tags, so is not likely related to that issue. 

What's interesting is that after the first failure, we see database errors for unique index constraints. Is it possible that the first error is leaving things in an inconsistent state that is leading to further retries failing?

```
ActiveRecord::RecordNotUnique: PG::UniqueViolation: ERROR:  duplicate key value violates unique constraint "index_ci_job_artifacts_on_job_id_and_file_type"
DETAIL:  Key (job_id, file_type)=(420918654, 1) already exists.
: INSERT INTO "ci_job_artifacts" ("project_id", "job_id", "file_type", "size", "created_at", "updated_at", "expire_at", "file", "file_sha256", "file_format") VALUES (REDACTED, REDACTED, 1, 243, '2020-01-30 16:06:34.384602', '2020-01-30 16:06:34.384602', '2020-02-06 16:06:33.646447', 'REDACTED', 'REDACTED', 2) RETURNING "id"

lib/api/runner.rb:300:
in `block (2 levels) in <class:Runner>', ee/lib/gitlab/ip_address_state.rb:10:
in `with', lib/api/api_guard.rb:168:in `call', ee/lib/omni_auth/strategies/group_saml.rb:41:
in `other_phase', ee/lib/gitlab/jira/middleware.rb:19:
in `call'
```


## Gitaly logs

Another concern was that this issue was not in the Gitaly logs. 

This implies that the network call never made it as far as Gitaly, or that the Gitaly logs were failing.

title: Strange milestone wrapping behavior on Releases page
description:
### Summary

The list of milestones at the top of each Release block is wrapping strangely:

![image](/uploads/472b71ff72d0963d0b92c89b44d1de42/image.png)

### Steps to reproduce

- Create a release with at least one milestone
- Navigate to the **Releases** page

### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/nfriend/release-test/-/releases

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

The milestones wrap.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The milestones should not wrap.

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com.

### Possible fixes

This probably isn't worth fixing since this UI will be reworked once https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/31289 is shipped.

title: Tech Evaluation: Bring your own Vault Integration
description:
### Problem to solve 
In the large vision for HashiCorp Vault we want to provide users access to Vault as a part of their GitLab experience natively - for both GitLab.com and self-managed instances. As a long term implementation we are evaluating and refining requirements on two main issues: 

1) [Bundling Vault with Omnibus](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/omnibus-gitlab/issues/4317) - this would allow users with Self-managed instances to have an integrated Vault with their GitLab Instance 
2) [Provide a single instance for GitLab.com](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/28584) - this would allow all users on GitLab.com to have a Vault instance with their GitLab account 

We have a lot of different directions and ways to support users in their journey to use Vault for Secrets Management with GitLab. 

As far as priorities go they are in this order: 
1) Support existing GitLab + Vault Users - "Bring your own Vault" (BYOV) 
2) Use Vault for Internal GitLab.com Secrets and Token 
3) Use Vault for Customers of GitLab.com Secrets Management Needs 
4) Support New Installations of Vault with Self-Managed Instances 

We will use this issue to establish the best path forward to support users with existing Vaults in the immediate term (use case 1). 

### Further details

In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/118624, we are evaluating the handling of secrets and tokens with the GitLab application. This can be the foundation for supporting use cases 2, 3, and 4. For some of our existing customers, their set up (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/28321#note_269481081) they do not want to have to use GitLab to store, administer, or update secrets - they want to defer all of this to Vault. As a result, we should investigate the most flexible way to support GitLab receiving tokens from Vault easily. 

This has been presented in two issues:
  A) [Identity API](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/24123) - where an API would identify which project/job a given Job Token belongs to (and is valid), then redirect users if token it not valid from the CLI 

  B) [Allow a user to set up Vault in K8](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/9982) - this would use the Vault Helm chart to install Vault but all configuration and managing of secrets would still be on the User and would likely require implementation of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/118624 to manage token/key/secrets passing 


### Next actions 

* [x] Get familiar with HashiCorp Vault and understand the issues link here
* [ ] Evaluate the easiest/quickest path to better support GitLab users that have a Vault with GitLab 
* [ ] Create or update issues for implementation, add weights and close this issue

title: Remove `pipeline.any_report_artifact_for_type` method
description:
`any_report_artifact_for_type` is used exclusively in [Pipeline Presenter](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/app/presenters/ee/ci/pipeline_presenter.rb#L22) 

The pipeline has an alternative method to fetch reports [`batch_lookup_report_artifact_for_file_type`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/2a15e2380a687555c7b6ae0623912a1c44ba6a0e/ee/app/models/ee/ci/pipeline.rb#L107)

We should use it since:
1. It improves performance: it reduces SQL calls and loads all reports in memory.
1. We'll unify the way we fetch reports in different features.

title: “Jump to next unresolved thread” button should show some context in merge request Changes tab
description:
Currently when using the “Jump to next unresolved thread” button in the merge request “Changes” tab one always has to scroll up a bit to see the line that the thread is referring to (to get some context).

When using that button, the scroll should stop to show up to 4 lines above the thread in the “Changes” tab. For comparison, today in the “Overview” tab we show up to 16 lines for inline threads.

| Current | Proposal |
|---|---|
| ![image](/uploads/329cc92daffbf211936313a2b5658669/image.png) | ![image](/uploads/c028d2fb57846e27e39a3ea1e97b0317/image.png) |

title: Remove “Jump to next unresolved thread” button in merge request threads
description:
Related to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/16798 and the discussion in its MR https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/23123#note_273084065.

Look at the tracking data in 4 milestones after https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/199458 is shipped. Revisit our decision of keeping both buttons and decide if we remove the “Jump to next unresolved thread” button present in each thread. If we decide to remove it, consider a popover that points at the global “Jump to…” button at the top of merge requests.

![image](/uploads/abedc40b8ef5c33038cb39822d04fa2f/image.png)

### Proposal

Given that the [usage of this button on GitLab.com](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/199718#note_367414996) is very low, let's remove it behind a feature flag. Once it's shipped we can turn the feature flag on in phases, giving enough time to listen to user feedback:
1. On for the GitLab.org group
1. Then on for GitLab.com
1. And then finally make it the default for all instances

title: Do not store `application_settings.static_objects_external_storage_auth_token` tokens in plaintext
description:
## Problem

With https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-foss/-/merge_requests/31025, we introduced new token fields (`application_settings.static_objects_external_storage_auth_token`) without digesting or encrypting the value. 

## Proposal

We shouldn't store any in plaintext and we should also migrate existing ones.

---

A follow-up issue for `users.static_object_token` https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/348163

title: Add conformity in package metadatum associations and validation
description:
If a package is associated with a metadata record from `conan_metadata`, `maven_metadata`, etc..., it should not be allowed to associate with another package metadata type, and it should be validated that the `package.package_type` matches the metadata type:

If `package.package_type = 'conan'`, then `package.conan_metadatum` should be possible, but `package.maven_metadatum` should not.

This was raised in the Composer package manager MR: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/22415#note_279046917

We can accomplish this with a `where` clause on the association:
```ruby
belongs_to :package, -> { where(package_type: :composer) }
```
as well as adding an additional validation to the metadatum table so when a record is created, the parent package record type is checked:

```ruby
  validate :composer_package_type

  private

  def composer_package_type
    unless package && package.composer?
      errors.add(:base, 'Package type must be Composer')
    end
  end
```

title: Export CNS (Cilium) Logs via SysLog
description:
### Problem to solve

<!-- What problem do we solve? -->
CNS users need visibility into the traffic that is passing through Cilium as well as the resulting decision (allow, log, block).  Without this visibility, it is difficult to custom tune Cilium rules as there is no easy way to verify that the rule is working as designed.  The current alternative of SSH'ing into each container to view the logs is inefficient for customers with lots of environments or containers, and provides the information in a format that is difficult to quickly interpret.  Ultimately, customers need an easy way to determine whether or not the Cilium rules are functioning as designed and to determine what attacks are occurring against the customer's application.

### Intended users

<!-- Who will use this feature? If known, include any of the following: types of users (e.g. Developer), personas, or specific company roles (e.g. Release Manager). It's okay to write "Unknown" and fill this field in later. -->

* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)

<!-- Personas are described at https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/ -->

### Proposal

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->

Note: some customers may choose to send the logs to a central logging solution before forwarding them on to a SIEM. The solution needs to work for this use case as well

Assumption: Nearly all GitLab Ultimate users are running a SIEM

Assumption: The customer will be responsible for ensuring a networking route exists between the SIEM and the deployed environment

* Users will be able to configure and save global settings to have Cilium logs exported to a SIEM or Central Logging Solution
* Global settings will be configured on the Settings -> Integration page and will include the following:
   * IP address or hostname
   * Port
   * Protocol (UDP or TCP)
* The format will be JSON format, will be sent via Syslog protocol, and will not be customizable
* The JSON will be sent on one line per message
* Global settings will be applied for all environments where Cilium is deployed
* Changes to global settings will be pushed to any environments where Cilium is already running
* Syslog messages will be sent from the K8 cluster directly to the specified IP address

### Designs

![SIEM1](/uploads/e39e5b5ddce2922c131449f165208642/SIEM1.png)

![SIEM3](/uploads/82fa61147ad2dedd07d833f46b1e6734/SIEM3.png)

### Not Required Functionality

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->
Functionality that is planned for the future but is **not** required to meet the requirements of this issue include the following:
* The ability to view the logs directly in GitLab will not be considered at this point

### Permissions and Security

<!-- What permissions are required to perform the described actions? Are they consistent with the existing permissions as documented for users, groups, and projects as appropriate? Is the proposed behavior consistent between the UI, API, and other access methods (e.g. email replies)?-->
Permissions should be consistent with the GitLab permission model

### Documentation

<!-- See the Feature Change Documentation Workflow https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature-change-workflow.html
Add all known Documentation Requirements here, per https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature-change-workflow.html#documentation-requirements
If this feature requires changing permissions, this document https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/permissions.html must be updated accordingly. -->
Documentation for Container Network Security does need to be updated to describe how to configure CNS SIEM settings

### Availability & Testing

<!-- What risks does this change pose to our availability? How might it affect the quality of the product? What additional test coverage or changes to tests will be needed? Will it require cross-browser testing? 

Please list the test areas (unit, integration and end-to-end) that needs to be added or updated to ensure that this feature will work as intended. Please use the list below as guidance.
* Unit test changes
* Integration test changes
* End-to-end test change

See the test engineering planning process and reach out to your counterpart Software Engineer in Test for assistance: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/#test-planning -->
The following tests will be performed as appropriate:
* Unit tests
* End-to-end tests
* Test with at least one SIEM (Note: Sending via Syslog will make us compatible with 99% of the SIEMs, so testing with just one to confirm connectivity will be adequate)

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

<!-- Define both the success metrics and acceptance criteria. Note that success metrics indicate the desired business outcomes, while acceptance criteria indicate when the solution is working correctly. If there is no way to measure success, link to an issue that will implement a way to measure this. -->
Success Criteria:
* Users are able to view their Cilium logs in a SIEM

Acceptance Criteria:
* Latency from the time a log is generated to when it is sent to the SIEM is not greater than one minute

### What is the type of buyer? 

<!-- Which leads to: in which enterprise tier should this feature go? See https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product/pricing/#four-tiers -->
~"GitLab Ultimate"

title: New SCIM users not created with group SAML connection
description:
### Summary

Users not previously sync'ed are being created in GitLab.com but without a SAML link to the group, unverified, and without terms of use accepted.

### Steps to reproduce

In Azure AD, 

1. Turn on SCIM for the first time.

or

1. Add new users (no existing account) to SCIM setup.

### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-silver/-/saml

should have this user: https://gitlab.com/admin/users/GitLab37

Turned on SCIM sync for the first time at approximately 10:30 UTC, which created the user, but unverified email, unconfirmed user, not a member of `gitlab-silver`.

This is what happened:

- this user was created: https://gitlab.com/admin/users/GitLab37
however user is unconfirmed, unverified, not a member of the group
- I had to sign in via AzureAD as the user then it asked me to accept the TOS, which I did,
- then it asked me to "Authorize" the app, which I did
- now the user shows up as a member of the group
- though still unconfirmed (since i don't even know how to access the inbox for that user)

identity part of API response for this user:

```
| identities       |                                        |
|------------------|----------------------------------------|
| provider         | "group_saml"                           |
| extern_uid       | "00377106-2df4-4815-bcd7-09f1cc4a1008" |
| saml_provider_id | 7                                      |
```

For additional context, please see (internal) [Slack thread](https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/CLM1D8QR0/p1580208618026800)

Originally reported by customer via (internal) https://gitlab.zendesk.com/agent/tickets/145008

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

User is created, but unverified email, unconfirmed user, not a member of `gitlab-silver`.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

User should be created and added to the group.

### Output of checks

GitLab.com, GitLab Enterprise Edition 12.7.0-pre 33d6233e83b

## Workaround

1. Have users confirm their account. If they need a new confirmation email: https://gitlab.com/users/confirmation/new
1. Reset their password.
1. Sign into GitLab if not already. Accept the Terms of use if prompted.
1. Have the affected user sign into Azure AD.
1. Access GitLab through the list of available apps (or using the Azure app's User access URL, also known as the **GitLab single sign on URL** on the GitLab SAML settings page with the token).
1. In GitLab, authorize the SSO app.

title: Track “Jump to next unresolved thread” buttons usage in merge requests
description:
Related to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/16798 and the discussion in its MR https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/23123#note_273084065.

We want to track both “Jump to next unresolved thread” buttons usage in merge requests to understand how people use them over time. Our hypothesis is that over time the usage of the “Jump to…” button in each thread will decline in favor of the global “Jump to…” button at the top of merge requests.

![image](/uploads/c4d4e3448ed20d0fd724766bf7be2d10/image.png)

To implement this, take a look at the [FE tracking guide](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/event_tracking/frontend.html). As an example, a similar tracking issue was recently addressed in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/23523.

title: API endpoint for code coverage graph
description:
### Problem to solve

Getting data for code coverage over time is a manual slow process today. This is described in full in the [issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/33743) to display the graph.

It is too slow to get the data every time the graph is drawn from the `ci builds` table.

### Intended users
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
 

### Further details

<!-- Include use cases, benefits, and/or goals (contributes to our vision?) -->

N/A - This is a backstage feature, won't be accessible.

### Proposal

This focuses on figuring out how to retrieve and store the code coverage data from the `ci_builds` table that will be used by the graph. The API endpoint will then be consumed by the ~frontend on https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/33743.

Given there could be a number of different jobs that would run code coverage in a project, we will have to split this into 2 endpoints:

1. For fetching all the available job names for the past 3 months. The values returned here will be rendered in the dropdown.
2. For fetching the coverage values for the past 3 months for the given job name.

### Permissions and Security

<!-- What permissions are required to perform the described actions? Are they consistent with the existing permissions as documented for users, groups, and projects as appropriate? Is the proposed behavior consistent between the UI, API, and other access methods (e.g. email replies)?-->

This is not a public API but rather will be used by the frontend to fetch data through AJAX requests.

### Documentation

<!-- See the Feature Change Documentation Workflow https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature-change-workflow.html
Add all known Documentation Requirements here, per https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature-change-workflow.html#documentation-requirements
If this feature requires changing permissions, this document https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/permissions.html must be updated accordingly. -->

No documentation change.

### Availability & Testing

<!-- What risks does this change pose to our availability? How might it affect the quality of the product? What additional test coverage or changes to tests will be needed? Will it require cross-browser testing? 

Please list the test areas (unit, integration and end-to-end) that needs to be added or updated to ensure that this feature will work as intended. Please use the list below as guidance.
* Unit test changes
* Integration test changes
* End-to-end test change

See the test engineering planning process and reach out to your counterpart Software Engineer in Test for assistance: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/#test-planning -->

#### Questions
* What's the rate limiting on this look like?
  * This would follow the same rate limiting from the other AJAX endpoints we have.
* Is the time range customizable?
  * For now, we won't accept any custom time range and have this always return data within 3 months.
* What if there is no data yet?
  * The API would return an empty hash or array

#### Test areas
* Unit test changes 
  * Feature requires new unit tests 
    * FE
    * API
* Integration test changes

title: GitLab pages domain verification status notification not sent to repository owner
description:
### Summary

When configuring a custom domain for a project utilizing GitLab pages, a successful domain verification results in a notification email being sent to all project maintainers. Project owners, however, do not receive this notification. Similar behavior is seen when domain verification fails. Because any member with the owner role is implicitly a maintainer, it is expected that any notification sent to the maintainers would also be sent to the owners.

While we've only encountered this issue in the context of domain verification, it may not be (likely isn't) limited to these notifications.

### Steps to reproduce

Trigger domain verification status notification, such as domain verification success or failure

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

When configuring a custom domain for a project utilizing GitLab pages, a successful domain verification results in a notification email being sent to all project maintainers, but project owners receive no such notification.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Project owners should receive the same email notifications received by the maintainers.

title: Move remove list option to the settings list
description:
### Problem to solve

As part of our[WIP limits MVC](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/11403)- we are taking one step toward decluttering the board list headers and giving the most used items more hierarchy by moving that `delete list` option the the list settings drawer. This is a similar pattern to `move issue` in issue sidebars, and will change no interaction other than the placement of the `delete` option.

### Proposal

![image](/uploads/5d48af92c26fee6482e54a38041a81b1/image.png)

*  Move `Delete list` or `Remove list` as a button in the drawer. It should be the last item.
*  Clicking the button triggers the modal as is the current pattern.
*  Once the option to `delete` is confirmed, the list disappears and the drawer closes.


### Things to consider

* How this impacts lists in tiers lower than Starter (where WIP limits is accessed)
  - Enable toggling on list settings, hide WIP limits field...we'll add more stuff later to Core so this future proofs the UX a bit. 
* Should `Delete` actually be titled `Removed` given that it is removing, not deleting?
  - Yes. Great idea. 
* Use Pajamas!

# THE BUTTON SHOULD BE `REMOVE` NOT `DELETE`

title: Code review start time doesn't account for approvals
description:
### Summary

On the code review analytics only the first comment is being considered for the beginning of a review. If the MR has received a previous approval that should also be considered. The earliest timestamp of first approval or first comment should be the beginning of the review.


### What is the current behavior?

Since there were no comments review time is shown as undefined.

![image](/uploads/a6ba64a5a6c7c569d856afe76ab5b3ba/image.png)

The actual issue is not fully apparent yet in the screenshot, but it will be in our face once gitlab-org/gitlab#197883 is in. There will be an entry for approver (possibly multiple), but yet an undefined review time.

### What is the preferred behavior?

I expected to see that review time was 2 hours.

### Possible fixes

It appears, the following needs to be done:
* [ ]  Review time computation should be [updated here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/lib/ee/api/entities.rb#L1040)
* [ ]  But since the MRs ordered in the descending of [review_time](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/lib/api/analytics/code_review_analytics.rb#L20), we should also update the definition of [ordering on review_time here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/app/models/ee/merge_request.rb#L73), which is used by `sort_by_attribute` [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/app/models/ee/merge_request.rb#L95).
* [ ]  Then there's also computing the grouping columns [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/app/models/ee/merge_request.rb#L106).

title: Make Group Export groups serialisation non-recursive
description:
Currently when using `GroupTreeSaver` to serialize and export group and it's children (subgroups) it uses recursive approach. 

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/lib/gitlab/import_export/group_tree_saver.rb#L29-36
```ruby
def serialize(group, relations_tree)
  group_tree = tree_saver.serialize(group, relations_tree)

  group.children.each do |child|
    group_tree['children'] ||= []
    group_tree['children'] << serialize(child, relations_tree)
  end

  group_tree
  rescue => e
    @shared.error(e)
  end
end
```

This approach makes it difficult to optimize serialization process in the future (streaming approach using `.ndjson` format).

@ayufan made a good suggestion to use iterative approach instead of a recursive one. 

```
build an enumerator, and add them to the queue of items to serialize
I believe we can have single SQL query to get the group and all subgroups in one go
serialize the content of the enumerator 
this ends-up nicely in ndjson
as it is flat list of small objects
then each group can have their own json of sub relations to serialize, or use json
```

title: Identification of historical releases in the UI
description:
### Problem to solve

#### User story

As a user, I want to be able to identify release items that were created with a date in the past, so I can understand that release and know what to expect regarding the evidence collection, which is not present in historical releases.

### User experience goal

Users would be able to identify when a Release is created with a date in the past through a label and timestamp in the UI.

#### Problem overview

When a Release is created with a future `released_at` attribute, it is identified as an **Upcoming Release** ([see documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/releases/#upcoming-releases)). This affects the creation of Evidence: with https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/38103, Evidence creation is scheduled for the `released_at` timestamp, rather than when the Release object was created.

There is also the concept of **historical releases**, when a Release is created with a date in the past. In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/38103 no Evidence is created for these Releases, as it is not easily known which milestones and issues were present at this historical data.

Within the Release model, a helper method identifies historical Releases. 

### Intended users

* [Rachel (Release Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#rachel-release-manager)
* [Parker (Product Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#parker-product-manager)
* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Presley (Product Designer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#presley-product-designer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)

### UX DoD (Definition of Done)

<details>
<summary>Click to see the UX DoD (Definition of Done) tasks 🔽</summary>

#### Entry Criteria for Design

- [ ] Problem has been validated
- [ ] Has UX effort accounted for in long term cycle, _we know unknowns_

#### Criteria for UX DoD

- [x] ~UX label is added to the issue
- [x] User stories and acceptance criteria have been created
  - [ ] Edge cases were considered
- [ ] Cross-team dependencies have been identified, if applicable
- [ ] Prototype or mock for each user story have been created
  - [ ] Empty states
  - [ ] Responsiveness
- [x] If changes involve copy, ~"UI text" label has been added
- [x] Pajamas: UI Component design have been identified
  - [ ] Pajamas issue is created (new workflow)
- [x] Marked as Ready for engineering evaluation per user story moved into ~"workflow::planning breakdown" & ~"needs weight" 

#### Entry Criteria for Ready for Development

- [ ] Scope has been defined and reviewed with engineering
- [ ] User stories have been weighed and are less than **5 MRs**
- [ ] Create new issues for follow up user stories

#### Criteria for Engineering DOD ([in addition to defined process](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/contributing/merge_request_workflow.html#definition-of-done)) 

- [ ] UX review for MRs that include user experience changes - mandatory for ~frontend that has impact to UI/UX
- [ ] Update SSOT in issues:
   - [ ] Update prototypes of deliverables
   - [ ] Add link to documentation
- [ ] Create new issues for follow up and open scope
</details>

### Proposal

* In the API, a release can be created with the `released_at` attribute in the past (as in, prior to the date in the user's local environment/GitLab instance).
* If a past `released_at` is used, no Evidence is collected for the Release ([see documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/releases/#schedule-release-evidence-collection)).
* When the `released_at` attribute is set in a past date, and the release is created/updated, the release item in the UI should display a badge component next to the release title.
  * The label should read: `Historical release`
  * A tooltip should be displayed on hover: `This release was created with a date in the past. Evidence collection at the moment of the release is unavailable.`
  * ~frontend use the Neutral color (gray) for the badge.
  * ~frontend verify the possibility to use the [gitlab-ui Badge component](https://gitlab-org.gitlab.io/gitlab-ui/?path=/story/base-badge--default)
  * ~frontend & ~UX should comply with the [Pajamas Badge Guidelines](https://design.gitlab.com/components/badge/)
* The release timestamp in the UI should read: `Created <timestamp> ago by`, followed by the user avatar. Hovering the copy should display a detailed timestamp.
  * ~frontend make an update to the ~"UI text" 
* Ordering of release items in the overview page. Releases should be displayed following the **most recent** to **older** order in the Releases overview page, ordered by the `released_at` attribute. For example:

```
- v5.1 feb 2020 (Upcoming release)
- v5.0 jan 2020
- v4.0 dec 2019
- v3.0 nov 2019 (Historical release)
- v2.0 oct 2019
- ...
```

title: Group invite doesn't give expected permission level
description:
### Summary

If a group is invited as members to other group using "Invite group" and a "Max access level" is given, it is not taken into account as expected. If a user on the group invited is "Maintainer" and "Max access level" has been set as "Reporter", that user still has "Maintainer" permission level on that new group to where his group has been invited.

Also, if user on group invited is "Reporter", and "Max access level" has been set as "Developer", the user is promoted to developer on this group. This is inconsistent.

Side note: There's no documentation on "Max access level" for "Invite group".

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a groupA with members and invite a userA as member.
2. Set user permission level to "Maintainer".
3. Create another groupB.
4. Use "Invite group" and invite groupA to this group.
5. Set "Max access level" to "Reporter".
6. Log with the userA account.
7. Check that you actually have "Maintainer" permissions on the groupB.

### Example Project

This is an example of a group. It has another group invited as members, with "Max access level" set to "Reporter".
https://gitlab.com/testing-group-invite2

User @kryword should have no maintainer access to projects in testing-group-invite2, but it has. It should be limited to Reporter.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Permission level set for members of invited group is the ***less*** restrictive between "Max access level" and the permissions of the user on the group invited.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Permission level set for members of invited group should be the ***most*** restrictive between "Max access level" and the permissions of the user on the group invited

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com

### Possible fixes

Swap current behaviour to use the most restrictive permission level between "Max access level" and the permission of the user on the group invited, instead of using the less restrictive.

Also document "Max access level" on the wiki.

title: Project integrations inherit instance level settings by default
description:
We are implementing https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/2430 to transition Service Templates to an inheritable instance-level configuration as part of the [mass-integration epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/2137).

This is an iteration that will enable us to eventually accomplish the next goal of group-level integration settings from which projects can inherit by default.  

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/196525 defines the UI work for moving Service Templates into Integration settings in the Admin Area. When this UI change goes live, the change from service templates to a default inheritance should also go live.

**Current Behavior (Service Template):** If a service template is enabled, a project-specific service record is copied from the template. Modifying the service template does not modify the service/integration settings for the new project.

**Desired Behavior (Instance-Level Integration):** When the instance-level integration is enabled, we do not create a new service record when a new project is created, and the project inherits the instance-level settings. A user can deactivate the integration at the project level or override the inheritance by entering custom values. This triggers the creation of a project-specific service record to override the instance-level settings.

title: Repositories#Archive returns 500 with invalid URLs
description:
### Summary

When trying to download a repositories archive, if you add extra characters to the end of the URL or do not include the `.zip` or other formats, you receive a 500 instead of a 404.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Navigate to a project (IE: `https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab`)
2. Append the URL with `/-/archive/master/gitlab-master.zip''` or `/-/archive/master/gitlab-master`

Note the correct URL would be `https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/archive/master/gitlab-master.zip` which works.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

URLs with invalid formats return a 500 instead of a 404.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Users should receive a 404.

#### Results of GitLab application Check

This happens on GitLab.com

### Possible fixes

While the URL itself returns a 500, the 500 is coming from workhorse. Rails actually finds the best guess (last commit) and returns a 200, but workhorse is then delegated to handle the response. Workhorse returns an "Invalid format" error, but that is not captured anywhere and it happens after the request has already been "handled." It may be best to return 404 for any requests to this endpoint (in Rails) that do not match the path regex (`/(zip|tar|tar\.gz|tgz|gz|tar\.bz2|tbz|tbz2|tb2|bz2)/`).

title: Export WAF Logs via SysLog
description:
### Problem to solve

<!-- What problem do we solve? -->
WAF users need visibility into the traffic that is passing through the WAF as well as the resulting decision (allow, log, block).  Without this visibility, it is difficult to custom tune WAF rules as there is no easy way to verify that the rule is working as designed.  The current alternative of SSH'ing into each container to view the logs is inefficient for customers with lots of environments or containers, and provides the information in a format that is difficult to quickly interpret.  Ultimately, customers need an easy way to determine whether or not the WAF rules are functioning as designed and to determine what attacks are occurring against the customer's application.

### Intended users

<!-- Who will use this feature? If known, include any of the following: types of users (e.g. Developer), personas, or specific company roles (e.g. Release Manager). It's okay to write "Unknown" and fill this field in later. -->

* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)

<!-- Personas are described at https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/ -->

### Proposal

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->
Although we would like to eventually have Defend logs visible in the GitLab UI, currently it would require a sizable percentage of the Defend engineering team's time to make that possible.  Exporting the logs out to a customer's SIEM is the cheapest and fastest path to making the logs available and visible to our customers.  For that reason, the proposed implementation of this feature has shifted to focus on building UI that will allow for easy export of logs out to an external SIEM.  At some future point in time, we can revisit a path to also make the logs visible in GitLab, as the two are not mutually exclusive.

Note: some customers may choose to send the logs to a central logging solution before forwarding them on to a SIEM.  The solution needs to work for this use case as well

Assumption: Nearly all GitLab Ultimate users are running a SIEM

Assumption: The customer will be responsible for ensuring a networking route exists between the SIEM and the deployed environment

* Users will be able to configure and save global settings to have WAF logs exported to a SIEM or Central Logging Solution
* Global settings will be configured on the Settings -> Integration page and will include the following:
   * IP address or hostname
   * Port
   * Protocol (UDP or TCP)
* The format will be JSON format, will be sent via Syslog protocol, and will not be customizable
* The JSON will be sent on one line per message
* Global settings will be applied for all environments where WAF is deployed
* Changes to global settings will be pushed to any environments where WAF is already running
* Syslog messages will be sent from the K8 cluster directly to the specified IP address

### Designs

![SIEM1](/uploads/e39e5b5ddce2922c131449f165208642/SIEM1.png)

![SIEM3](/uploads/82fa61147ad2dedd07d833f46b1e6734/SIEM3.png)

### Not Required Functionality

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->
Functionality that is planned for the future but is **not** required to meet the requirements of this issue include the following:
* The ability to view the logs directly in GitLab will not be considered at this point

### Permissions and Security

<!-- What permissions are required to perform the described actions? Are they consistent with the existing permissions as documented for users, groups, and projects as appropriate? Is the proposed behavior consistent between the UI, API, and other access methods (e.g. email replies)?-->
Permissions should be consistent with the GitLab permission model

### Documentation

<!-- See the Feature Change Documentation Workflow https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature-change-workflow.html
Add all known Documentation Requirements here, per https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature-change-workflow.html#documentation-requirements
If this feature requires changing permissions, this document https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/permissions.html must be updated accordingly. -->
Documentation for WAF does need to be updated to describe how to configure WAF SIEM settings

### Availability & Testing

<!-- What risks does this change pose to our availability? How might it affect the quality of the product? What additional test coverage or changes to tests will be needed? Will it require cross-browser testing? 

Please list the test areas (unit, integration and end-to-end) that needs to be added or updated to ensure that this feature will work as intended. Please use the list below as guidance.
* Unit test changes
* Integration test changes
* End-to-end test change

See the test engineering planning process and reach out to your counterpart Software Engineer in Test for assistance: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/#test-planning -->
The following tests will be performed as appropriate:
* Unit tests
* End-to-end tests
* Test with at least one SIEM (Note: Sending via Syslog will make us compatible with 99% of the SIEMs, so testing with just one to confirm connectivity will be adequate)

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

<!-- Define both the success metrics and acceptance criteria. Note that success metrics indicate the desired business outcomes, while acceptance criteria indicate when the solution is working correctly. If there is no way to measure success, link to an issue that will implement a way to measure this. -->
Success Criteria:
* Users are able to view the logs for their WAF in a SIEM

Acceptance Criteria:
* Latency from the time a log is generated to when it is sent to the SIEM is not greater than one minute

### What is the type of buyer? 

<!-- Which leads to: in which enterprise tier should this feature go? See https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product/pricing/#four-tiers -->
~"GitLab Ultimate" 

### Technical Discovery

In case there is a need to create a new table (to save the information of the target host), it should have a reference [cluster table](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/db/structure.sql#L1573).

The information save in the DB could used in order to add a second host into [ELK custom values](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/vendor/elastic_stack/values.yaml#L25). [Filebeat documentation](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/beats/filebeat/current/configuring-output.html) is not very clear if this is an elastic search host only or any host. Otherwise we could look into integrating a syslog solution for supporting a wider number of hosts.

A reinstallation of ELK might be required (`helm update --install`) or an update of the configmap `values-content-configuration-elastic-stack`.

title: Development of Release CLI
description:
### Problem to solve

Effect the instruction in the `:release` node of `.gitlab-ci.yaml`. These instructions are converted into command line commands and passed to the Runner. The Runner then calls a to-be-developed CLI and passes the commands to it. 

The MVC supports creation of a Release object in Rails, based on definitions in `.gitlab-ci.yml`. The Release is created with **name** and **description**. Description can be passed from a file inside the repo, eg: `CHANGELOG.md`

```
release_upload:
  image: registry.gitlab.com/gitlab-org/release-cli:v0.1.0
  script:
    - gitlab-releaser create --name="My Release" --description="My Release description"
```

* Note: The CLI name and commands are not finalised.


### Intended users

* [Rachel (Release Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#rachel-release-manager)
* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)


### Proposal

Develop a Release CLI tool to implement `.gitlab-ci.yaml` instructions. The CLI will be developed in Golang and is launched in a Docker environment by the Runner. The commands will be assembled by the GitLab Rails and passed to this CLI by the Runner.

In this iteration, the Release CLI will:

- Use the [GitLab Release CLI](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/release-cli) docker image
- Support `--name` and `--description` params
- Call the [Releases API](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/releases/#create-a-release) to create a Release with `name` and `description`


The CLI will have access to all [CI variables](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/variables/). The MVC will need to access two variables:

- `$CI_JOB_TOKEN` - for authentication to the GitLab Releases API
- `$CI_PROJECT_ID` - project ID in which to create the Release

### Permissions and Security

Authentication via `$CI_JOB_TOKEN`, available as an environment variable in the Docker container.

### Documentation

Yes, this change will require documentation.

<!-- See the Feature Change Documentation Workflow https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature-change-workflow.html
Add all known Documentation Requirements here, per https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature-change-workflow.html#documentation-requirements
If this feature requires changing permissions, this document https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/permissions.html must be updated accordingly. -->
